title: To what extent was communism a cause of WW2? - Quora

response.answer_text: One of the tropes I hate seeing in movies or TV shows is when the Bad Guy kills someone because the Good Guy did not do something, then the Good Guy laments that the death is THEIR fault, not the fault of the person who killed them. I know that it’s both a reflection of the rigid moral compass needed to be a Good Guy, as well as a natural instinct for some to take responsibility for situations they could not possibly have affected if they feel somehow involved… but you’d think that people so involved in the actions of Good AND Bad in such a matrix would have dealt with that a long time ago. That’s also the root of this question. Communism itself was NOT a cause of WW2. Nazis hating Communism was. More important than that, Nazis from Germany wanting to invade Russia for their resources, and effectively starve the “inferior” Russian people to death while expanding the German people to fill all that land. The Nazis used Communism as an excuse to villainize Russia, and enact their extremist plan. The Communists had their own issues. And Stalinism — which, despite its mischaracterization by many on BOTH sides, was effectively Despotism dressed in Red mouthing Communist rhetoric to justify itself — had TONS of issues stemming from its own addiction to power. But to blame the Communists for “making Germany angry” is like blaming the new kid for getting beat up for being new because it “taunted” the bullies.

It depends what part you’re talking about. It didn’t have anything to do with Japan in China. It didn’t have anything to do with Germany annexing Austria, or going into Czechoslovakia or Poland, or Belgium, or France. It’s hard to say if going further east was motivated by Soviet Communism, or hatred of ethnic Slavs. Going back, it’s not clear that the rise of the NSDAP was anti-communist or just right wing reactionary anti-liberal anything. This is not to say that Hitler didn’t spend a lot of vitriol against the Communists. It’s more that he may have been saying similar things against anybody to the left of Bismarck.
